decision.reasoning:
The current market implies SEA wins 61.5% of the time, which is unusually high for a Super Bowl matchup unless there‚Äôs a large underlying efficiency gap. The hard-data snippets don‚Äôt support a gap that big:

- Explosives: Seahawks have the best explosive-play differential (+4.7 pp), but the Patriots profile is also elite: ESPN notes NE is 4th (+2.8 pp) and has the league-best offensive explosive creation rate (13.6%). That‚Äôs not a ‚ÄúSEA by a mile‚Äù profile‚Äîmore like two top-tier teams.
- Patriots‚Äô playoff run was defense-driven (16-3, 28-16, 10-7). Low-scoring, controlled games usually indicate a defense that can keep variance down‚Äîvaluable against a favored opponent.
- Maye‚Äôs profile (high tight-window rate) adds turnover risk, but it also signals an offense capable of converting difficult throws‚Äîi.e., they can still generate chunk plays even when covered. Against a high-priced favorite, I prefer the side with credible explosive upside plus a strong defense.

Given the market is already pricing SEA like a clear tier above NE, I see value on NO at 38.5% (i.e., Pats win). My estimated Pats win chance is closer to the mid-40s than high-30s based on the closeness of explosive metrics and NE‚Äôs defensive/low-variance postseason path.
